content.webTitle: José Mourinho says Juventus’ spending can win them Champions League

fields.headline: José Mourinho says Juventus’ spending can win them Champions League
fields.bodyText: José Mourinho has described Juventus as major contenders in this season’s Champions League because of the money they have invested, sending a none-too-subtle coded message not only to his former club Real Madrid but his present employers, Manchester United. Cristiano Ronaldo will be making a return to Old Trafford with the £88m recruit’s new side as a result of Juventus being drawn in the same Champions League group as United, and Mourinho believes the Italian club’s summer spending is a sign of their naked ambition. “They don’t hide,” he said admiringly, having previously gone public with his own disappointment at United’s failure to land more than one of his transfer targets. “Juventus are always a big candidate in the European competitions but the investment they made shows they want to win it this time. “We are going to try to win, even against that big team, even though Cristiano is still a top player. I think he likes to come back here, he did when he was with Real Madrid, but of course when he returns with a new team he comes to do a job. For them.” Mourinho wanted at least one more central defender in the summer transfer window, with Harry Maguire and Toby Alderweireld among the names mentioned, and though his grumbling about the club’s parsimony appeared to unsettle his back line in the defeats by Brighton and Tottenham, he still maintains that defensive errors are all that stands between United and a good start to the season. “We want to play the way we did in the first half against Tottenham,” he said. “In that match we were really strong and really positive against a very good opponent and we could tell Spurs were finding it hard, but two defensive mistakes in five minutes cost us the game. “To be really good offensively you have to be solid at the back, all the best teams are, because that is what allows you the confidence to take risks. We are willing to play in a way that carries risk, but if you make mistakes in defence it breaks the dynamic.” Alexis Sánchez is expected to be back in the starting lineup when United travel to Burnley on Sunday but will not be joining up with the Chile squad for their two Asian friendlies during the international break. Mourinho said: “It is his own decision, I never ask players not to play for their country or interfere with selection. Alexis had a good pre-season but then picked up a small injury, and he feels he needs a couple of weeks after Burnley to put himself in good shape.” After surprising everyone in the early weeks of last season, Burnley have made an even slower start than United this time, with one point from three games. Burnley can probably handle successive defeats, however, whereas at United it makes everyone nervous. “I said before the start of the season that matching what we did last season was going to be difficult,” Mourinho said. “I knew that because finishing second last season was difficult. If I say it again now it is not because of two defeats. “We have lost six points but there are still 30-odd games to play. We would have liked to have made a better start but last season we won our first four games and then lost a couple of matches. Maybe this time we will have the defeats first and then the consecutive victories. My only target at the moment is to win at Burnley and then win against Watford [on 15 September], and then we can start thinking of the Champions League.”
